title: What Can Search Tell Us? A Human-Centered Perspective
segmentation: OK, so first I want to thank the organizers for the invitation.
I'm really honored and happy to be here and see that there is a great audience.
So this is title of the talk.
What can search tell us?
A human centered perspective?
I'll talk about some high level ideas, some research that we've been doing in the products that have been impacted by that research.
So the first question I have for you guys is many of you took the elevator.
How many of you notice what's written on the walls of the elevator?
Raise your hands.
Only a few people so.
This relates to the first slide that I have and the first question I had, you know, is what is search.
When I came in when I started making the slides.
So I think.
Well what is search?
So I looked in.
The dictionary, but before that, before I get into that, you know the field started with information retrieval, so it was all about getting information.
You make a query, you get something, but the reality is that this is not really what we're doing anymore in my view.
What we're doing now is.

Really information interaction at every level when we interact with the desktop or the mobile device and we're using media really as a form of mediation in terms of communicating with other people, communicating with our environment, and so on and so forth.
But let's go back to the.
Definition so if you look at the dictionary definition, it says it's trying to find something or someone by seeking carefully scrutinizing throughly.
OK, so that's quite interesting, but if you go deeper you look at the you know where it comes from and it comes from a Latin go round or circle.
So then it becomes even more interesting because it becomes.
It's very obvious very quickly that it's not a punctual activity and we've been looking at search as a, you know query.
Click pair, and that's not what it is at all.
You know it's really a series of activities around a specific goal, but that's also very complicated.
Cause.
You know, as.
We all know we often get distracted or goals change as we're performing the search.
The goals were not specific and so on, so it's a process.
And then if you look.
Get the thesaurus for search.
There are many, many awards which.
Again, if you read this, I mean, at least for me, this this is what happens.
It really applies to what I do when I'm searching.
You know, I do all kinds of things when I'm searching.
It's not just a single query, it's a very long process and there are many, many implications to this.
So the point that I want to make with this is that if we really want to support search, we need to consider its complex practical aspects and stop thinking about it as a query results list.
Situation OK, the main points of this though.
Our first of all that it's not a single query.
We never do a search with a single query or in rare cases, do we do that?
The second point is that it's usually not a single session.
You know.
When I was coming to Brussels, you know, I searched for the hotel.
You looked at the reviews for the hotel.
I looked for the flights, I contacted my travel agent.
There were many many steps involved in the search process, so it wasn't just a single session, it was many, many sessions overtime.
And then the context also changes their implicit implicit aspects about the search.
Their explicit aspects that are internal internal meaning, cognitive, state, emotional state, and so on, and then external contextual factors that go into account.
So we're doing work in that relates to to some of this, so I'll just give you some examples.
So what I'll do is I'll talk about different things and then give some very brief examples of this.
So one of the questions we had with not only with search but specifically with behavior within Flickr was.
How does behavior within Flickr, which is sort of an ecosystem in itself?
Depend on where people come from.
So if you think about it, you know Flickr is like it's own network and then people come to flicker from different places from search engines from Mail in from and so and so forth.
So we wanted to know if that within a network behavior depends on how users enter the network, which again relates to what I said earlier in terms of context.
You know people don't just come to flicker, they don't just appear, it flicker, they're doing something before they come to flicker, and this applies to every.
Web page into every search, right?
So before they issue a search query, they were doing something.
So what is it that they were doing before that?
Which implies changes in there?
Behavior so we wanted to do was, you know, see if we could find any patterns for different categories of sites that they visit before Flickr.
So what we did was.
We group them into.
We grouped the visiting URLs into different categories, including aggregators, photo sites, microblogs, blogs, shopping sites, social news, entertainment and Mail, and the details are in the paper.
This was published that I see me this year, but it's pretty interesting when you start looking at this.
So we found that, for example, when people come to Flickr from Mail clients, they tend to spend a lot more time.
Right when they come from aggregators, they spend a very short time and again this has a lot to do with the context, so we could assume we don't know this.

It's a hypothesis that when people come to flicker from Mail, it means they got a link from a friend, and Mail is usually a close contact, so it could be related to an event they attended, or if it's a close friend or more likely to look at more photos and spend more time right.
Whereas if they come from an aggregate, are you know some random new site?
Maybe they just want to see another photo of the same event and that's it they leave so they don't spend that much time.
And so if we look at if we cluster these behaviors and we look at the sources we find, for example, that.
When the source.
Is search mainly and then followed by news?
People tend to spend a lot of time in Group pages and photos of of the group, which again are very topic related to search and the specific news event when they come from aggregators.
They tend to go to pages on Flickr that have to do with recent activity.
So recent see, it's really important freshness.
When they come from Mail, they spend a lot of time managing friends and adding friends, so there's a very strong social link there, so again, the context goes beyond just flicker.
We need to look at what the users are doing before that.
And then the last one is search and this one is again quite interesting.
We found that when people come to Flickr from search engines, what they end up doing is they continue the search process on Flickr itself, OK?
So the main.
Observations the entry point of a user within an ecosystem such as such as Flickr, influences her behavior in terms of the session length, type of page visited, actions taken and engagement.

Instead of the main observations with Mail, we have longer sessions, strong focus on managing Contacts, the search task moves to Flickr and then aggregators move onto short sessions and image browsing.
Now different paper and I won't go into details with this one.
This was published at Cigar this year.
With a similar flavor, we wanted to sort of understand image ranking and again this relates to search when you search you expect to get a ranked list of items right?
So then we thought OK on Flickr.
There are many ways in which you can rank images.
We can use favorites.
We can use the time spent, the number of views we can use Pagerank or we can apply browse rank which was looks just looks at how you know the browsing patterns between images.
So we did a study of these different ranking methods and we found that.
Of course, the results are different for each ranking method and depending on which one you use, you emphasize either internal activities within this network, particularly in Flickr.
And if you use a different ranking method, you emphasize photos, there are more important externally.

So as an example, you know if there are photos that, let's say the Royal wedding, the Royal wedding photos were very popular because there was a lot of press coverage, so the emphasis is external if you go to Flickr.
And you look at the number of favorites of the Royal wedding photos.
They're probably not that many, right?
So if you use favorites to rank the images, those images would come out at a very low ranking.
And maybe the favorite ones would be like there's this scary house.
It's like an amusement park in Canada has a huge number of followers, and this is an internal phenomena within Flickr that they have this number.
So those images are not really relevant.
Perhaps for people outside of.
Flickr so understanding rankings also has to do with looking at where the important comes.
The importance comes from, is it within the network from outside the network so you can look at the details in the paper.
The second point that I want to talk about is how can search analysis be useful at large scale and?
I'll talk about five different dimensions, so one is personal information management, second algorithmic, to improve the results.
3rd one is consumer activities, 4th one is designed in terms of changing the user experience and then at the macro level there are a lot of things that we can do to leverage search.
Logs, so in terms of personal information management, I think we haven't really done much in this area.
My group, but I think it's an area which is interesting and I just wanted to mention it and encourage people to work on this.
You know what does my search history tell me about myself?
I don't know.
I don't look at it often enough.
I don't really have tools to do that easily enough.
You know, in a way that is compact and accessible and so on and so forth, but I think there are opportunities here to discover things about myself and keep track of resources and so on and so forth.
Algorithmic I think this one is fairly clear.
You know, by analyzing the search results.
Sorry, the search queries themselves to search itself.
We can do better ranking and so on and so forth.
In terms of.

The pages that are visited of course you know the famous search funnel is extremely important, so analyzing those searches and being able to tell websites or companies what state in the state in the search funnel the user is in or or the visitor is in is extremely.
Useful.
In terms of design.
Again, it's an area we haven't explored very much.

As soon as an example of this, I can't say that much about what we've done, because the work that the research work is not public yet, but we analyzed a very large set of query logs and we found, among other things, that people that do image search don't search the web for images the same way that they search the web for textual documents, and one of the main findings.
Is that people tend to search and then browse so you know in text search people you know enter query and then they click on things.
On image search, they tend to enter search and then spend a long time looking at many many images within that category.
So this is impacted.
Design of Yahoo image search.
And we're working on on making improvements and changes, so it's an example of how large scale log analysis can impact the design of a product.
And so as you see here.
I found a bunch of things which eventually we will publish, but you can see in the product itself now.
So I uploaded.
I copied this a few minutes ago and if you go now to the page it's already changed.
So this page.
This homepage is changing constantly, so freshness and diversity extremely important.
And then what you see here is categories because again we found by analyzing this large scale behavior that people tend to search within categories and browse within within categories.
So the classification is extremely.
Important in that sense and if you go to the page, you'll see many more categories below.
Below this one.
I think if I have time, I'll go back to it.
In another body of work which relates to some of these concepts is what we're what we call parallel search, and again, it's the complexity of search.
It's it's not a single query, it's not a single resultset.
We want to look at many things at once, and specifically with images it becomes quite complex, so this is a short.
Paper at ACM multimedia.

This year and if I have time, I'll show you the video, but what we did here is we've built system, I guess to search for images based on a parallel search paradigm and the way that it works is you type in a search query.

In this case the user typed in Angelina, Angelina Jolie and then you get different film strips OK, and for each film strip you get a separate set of search results and each filmstrip acts as an independent search window.
So the top one is just Angelina Jolie under Arts and Entertainment, the second one under people.
The third one under Angelina and Brad and the last one under politics.
And you can see that the images are very different.
And while all of the strips remain static, you can click on any of the strips and modify the search and see the changes immediately.
So it allows you to explore a collection using it.
A dimension of different features in parallel OK, and again if I have time, I'll show you the.
Video.
The other way in which search analysis can be used is at the macro level.
So if we look at large scale analysis and I'll give an example of that and then also in terms of marketing.
So this paper from Wisdom 2011 and what we wanted to understand here was OK. Do people with different demographic characteristics search in different ways?
And So what we did was we looked at 2.3 million active registered users.
We crossed the data with census data.
Just work with Ingmar Weber by the way, and the analysis was anonymous aggregated.
Once you know who searching in terms of demographics, what are they searching for and how and details?
During the paper, but we basically found clusters that had fairly consistent behavioral patterns.
So we found one cluster which we called baby boomers, which you know based on the observations on their behavior.
We found OK.
They tend to be older users.

They search for business and finance more navigational queries, liberal females, women, more shopping queries, more likely to have voted for Obama longer sessions, why Conservatives, older men, auto business, consumer electronics, less navigation.
And then what we call challenge youth younger lowering can.
Music more navigational.
In their related paper from CIKM, we did a similar thing, but we wanted to see whether.
Specific query was performed by different demographic groups at different times, so do younger people search for movies 1st and then older people?
And how did this change so I don't have time to go into the details, but that's the basic.
Idea in terms of product impact, this is a product that came out of our group and it's called Yahoo Clues and it shows you trending queries and demographic.
Formation and this is of course useful for marketing, and it's again based on large scale.
And Alice.
Then it shows you the queries that occur before and after a given query that you can type in.
Now what are the hot new areas?
First mobile in multi screen, second multimedia.
3rd social.
So mobile I think everything is mobile.
I think we should stop talking about mobile and just assume that everything is mobile.
Computing is mobile.

The screen this is 1 project we have not worked on but it was a product released recently by Yahoo which I think is very very interesting because it allows you to search on any device and you can continue the search on the other device and the results are visual.
So when you type in a search well first of all you get the trending searches and then you get images of the webpages but then you as you do the search you can just use the other device and continue.
It will ask you do you want to continue where you left off on your iPad or on the desktop.
So it's quite interesting.
I would encourage you to take a look at it.
So I think this I mean we do this now, right?
I mean I use my phone, I use my mobile device.
I use my laptop.
I use the desktop.
So it's a natural transition to be using multiple devices.
But if you look at most of the products that we use today, they don't really allow us to take that context into account.
So this is a good example of where whatever context we have is saved and continues on to the other.
Device.
This multimedia, I think is the hot area now, although we've been in this community for such a long time because if you look at social media platforms it's amazing.
But if we start to think about it really, almost all of the conversations were happening around images, so this is really, really significant and so it's the time to do to do some stuff here.
Social search, I'm not sure yet.
I think it's an area that is still starting.
We need to do a lot of work to figure out when it's valuable, when it's not.
One possibility, and this is from a paper we published last year, a test where we looked at business applications of social network analysis.
But if you look at these charts and again details in the paper, there are many places in which search in one way or the other play a key role specifically around social and and social networks.
So I skip this one again.
It's in the tape in the.
Paper and in terms of big data, you know.
Everyone's talking about big data.
Of course it's big.
It's huge, it's important, but I think what's more important than the size of it.
Data is is the way that this data is being generated and accessed.
So on one hand, data is increasingly more fragmented.
You know, were into this 140 character mode.
Everything is in little bits and pieces right?
And so if you think about this, this is significant because before you know we could search for something and get a single article with all the information.
Now this is not the case anymore.
If we really want to know what's happening with X topic or why topic we really need to.
Look at multiple sources at the same time in their own little tiny snippets.
So this fragmentation and aggregation is really crucial, and the same applies to multi authorship in the past.
Again, you know you would search for document and you get the document by one author.
Now you search for something in your tweets, you get updates from social media sites, you get blocked, posts, you get images, you get videos.
How do you aggregate all of this and make sense of it?
So it's a really, really big challenge.
And an I would say that up to a large extent, a lot of the success in this area depends on how we view and how we use connections.
It's all really about the connections between all of these different.

Thanks, and here's a quote that I like very much because it's extremely relevant to where we are today and in computing an apparent connection is stronger than once, which are obvious, and I wonder if anyone can guess when this quote was stated.
Nobody.
OK, it wasn't this year.
It was a little bit earlier.
But it is highly relevant so to.
Close my main points in terms of search.
You know it's not a single query.
There are many sessions.
Context is extremely important.
The second one was, you know, search is more than just search.
We can use the analysis in many, many different ways.
It's still open area.
The hot new areas that I talked about, mobile multi screen and big data.
You know what are the implications beyond the size.
You know it's not just the size, there are many other implications and.

And all of this work falls within what I call human centric computing, and this is sort of the framework where we try to focus everything on the user and then start either with hypothesis with designer with data.
But it's really a loop where things change and interact.
One with the other and then just a list of some of the papers from.
This year and it's I would say the key again.
Even with search I started with the definition it's looking at it from the perspective of an intersection between user experience data analysis and what I call human aspects.
If you look at only the algorithms then you continue to see it as a query link kind of thing.
OK.
Thank you.
For the hot topics you didn't mention personalized recommendations to use it incorporated into some other topics.
Or do you find it relevant?
Because there are companies like Netflix, for example, that emphasizes on the fact that people don't have to actively search anymore.
They are being recommended to.
How important is this characteristical kind of behavior?
On the services.
Yeah, so to me this is part of context, so I in my view it's included in what I said about context.
It's it's part of the context and that's that's where we failed up to some extent.
And you know, in terms of the research that we do, there are simple things.
I mean not always simple things, but there are things that we can do to look into that.
And the flicker is work is 1 example where we thought, OK, well, let's see what's happening before they even enter Flickr to try to get a better understanding of the context.
So in general there's a lot that can be done, and I think personalization is is very closely related to.
To context.
OK, thank you very much.
Thank you once again for your presentation.
